prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will scan almost the full band-6 using 8 different frequency setups, with a full coverage range of 212-272 GHz(60 GHz bandwidth). We choose this band to cover the CO emission at 0<z<4, [CII] emission at 6<z<8, and at the same time get a continuum map at unprecedented depth. Furthermore, this band provides a larger fractional bandwidth, larger field of view and better atmospheric transparency with respect to band-7. These compensate the fact that band-7 traces a higher part of the dust SED from distant galaxies.
We aim to cover the larger possible bandwidth while keeping enough velocity resolution to be able to resolve relatively narrow lines from distant galaxies (50 km/s line-width in some cases; see Carilli et al. 2013). We will use the correlator in FDM mode, with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband, making a total of 7.5 GHz per tuning, and using a spectral channel averaging factor of 16. This leads to approximately 10 km/s channel width. Including all 8 frequency tunings (one per science goal), we will be covering a total bandwidth of 60 GHz.
We are asking for the most simple possible setup and correlator output that will allow us to accomplish our scientific goals. We will not exceed the maximum allowed data rates.

We will use the ALMA C36-1 or C36-2 array configurations (both are acceptable) to obtain an angular resolution of roughly 1.0"-1.5" in band-6. This resolution is needed to dissentangle individual sources without out-resolving the emission, being most sensible to faint emission. We do not have special imaging requirements. We expect most of the sources to be point-like at the requested resolutions (1.0-1.5"), and thus do not require exquisite uv coverage. Similarly, we do not have special calibration requirements. We will use the observatory provided calibration.

We propose to perform a deep spectral line and continuum survey in a single pointing in the Hubble UDF. The unique depth and frequency coverage of this program will bring forth unexplored regimes which will lead to transformational science with ALMA in full array in later cycles.
Our goal is to reach a sensitivity in CO emission that is well below the knee of the H2-mass functions (Fig. 3). For line detections, we aim for a 1-sigma sensitivity of ~0.1 mJy per 300 km/s channel, which translates into a 5-sigma CO luminosity of ~ 7x10^8 K km/s pc^2 for a 300 km/s linewidth at a typical redshift z=1.5. For our calculations, we assume a typical linewidth of 300 km/s and use this as the bandwidth used for sensitivity calculations.
Depending on the actual CO excitation, this implies CO(1--0) luminosities of (1-7)x10^9 K km/s pc^2. This is a factor 3 to 10 below the knee of the CO luminosity function at this redshift. As discussed above, the same line sensitivity will also allow us to detect and confirm [CII] emission in a typical galaxy at z=6-8 with SFR ~ 10 M_sol/yr. Note that the candidate [CII] emission lines have fluxes of ~ 0.5-1.0 mJy. Reaching to an rms of 0.1 mJy per channel will allow us to unambiguously detect such lines (>5-sigma). For the full 60 GHz bandwidth, this translates into an rms level of 6 uJy in the continuum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our recent ALMA band-6 spectroscopic survey of a 1 arcmin^2 region in the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (UDF) has yielded about ten CO line candidates, sixteen continuum detections and, most interestingly, a handful of [CII] line emitting candidates at z>6. In this proposal, we seek to obtain a more than two times deeper spectral survey in band-6 in a single pointing field in order to capitalise over these exciting new results. Our main goals are to (1) constrain the CO luminosity function well into the regime of normal galaxies at z~1.5; Most importantly, (2) confirm the four [CII] line emitting candidates at z>6 in our target field. These deeper observations are the only means to confirm such z>6 sources, given the faintness of the Ly-alpha emission in the optical spectra, and will enable the exploration of the most sensitive flux levels in order to inform future deep molecular spectroscopy of the full UDF.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Catolica of Chile, Pontifica University
Centre of Astrophysics and Supercomputing, Swinburne University of Technology
Faculty of Physics, Valparaiso, University of
Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales
Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Catolica of Chile, Pontifica University
Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Catolica of Chile, Pontifica University
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
